Victor Dates: Slow, Precise and Careful
By BERNIE COHEN
After fifteen minutes of talk in an
ersatz conversation cluster of
Spartan wooden chairs, Victor Dates
offers a piece of hard candy, which
he takes from a drawer in his uncluttered desk.
Dates carefully unwraps his piece,
and neatly deposits the wrapper in a
shirt pocket.

Portrait
Victor Dates, now Secretary of the
University, is a large man who
played football and lacrosse as an
undergraduate here.
He works in an ancient but
respectably expansive second-floor
Homewood House office whose low,
downward-curving ceiling seems to
contain almost naturally his considered thoughts.
But there is somewhere an
uneasiness, a malaise.
"I think every administrator in
higher education in these times feels
pressure, but administrators learn

to live with and to work under
pressure."
Dates recalls that there were only.
two blacks in his class when he was
graduated from Hopkins in 1960.
But he said he sees a change. "I
think a great deal of progress has
been made in the recruitment of
black students to the University."
Dates is precise in denying that
Hopkins is a white racist institution.
"You have to put the term racist into
a correct context," he said.
"You have to look at the histories
of places like Hopkins. At one time, I
think that Hopkins was an all-white
University. That day has passed .. . .
"If you mean racist in the sense
that this is a bad or hostile place for
blacks to be, I think that is untrue."
Dates does not volunteer information. He answers questions
slowly and guardedly.
"I think the Black Students' Union
can be explained as a natural inclination," he said. "When you come
from a peer group that is largely
black to one that is 90 per cent white,
it is- natural to seek—out people Act.—

whom you feel close."

1960, Dates studied for his law
degree at the Georgetown Law
Center. He spent two years in the
Army,and then returned to Hopkins
five years ago as Director Cl Special
Programs, where he worked in the

areas of community affairs, civil

Computer Waste
After all the administration's claims that money is so
tight that departments must be eliminated and student
tuition and activities fees must rise, we find that $400,000
is being set aside for a third-generation computer to
keep Hopkins up with MIT and Yale.
The new computer (which would duplicate the thirdgeneration computers already present at the Hopkins
Hospital and APL) would cost Homewood at least
$500,000 yearly, gobbling up the $200 tuition hike within
the first year of operation. On top of that, the major user
departments say they don't really need the new computer. Clearly, as several hard-science professors
suggested, the Computer Center wants to play around
with new equipment--and build up their staff a bit too-at student and faculty expense. Evidently, some high
administrators have allowed the Computer Center to
build up a money reserve for the purchase or rental of
"sophisticated" machinery that alumni could marvel
over.
Hopkins' problem these days seems not to be a lack of
money so much as a lack of foresight and planning. To
eliminate the Education Department and the Russian
Program (who knows what department will be curtailed
this week), and at the same time gathering money for a
new computer of dubious merit should be seriously
quesioned by students and faculty.
Dean Benton's comment, "You don't have a story
here. I haven't made any decisions on the matter" is
illustrative of the administration's (and many times
faculty's) obsession with keeping major policy decisions
away from the public eye. Today the dean will hear the
case for the new computer; later this week he will
hopefully hear students and faculty opposed to such
technological waste.

People have a right to know how decisions are made,
and not simply be informed of them after the fact. That
is the spirit, if not the substance, of the summer
Governance Report.
Yet last Friday, the Committee on Undergraduate
Studies voted (six professors to two students) to bar the
press and other observers from their meeting. The
rationale was that a reporter on the sidelines would
inhibit their freedom to fully discuss and argue the
matters before them. Instead, the members voted to
hand the press after every meeting a no doubt carefully
worded release of what happened.

readers should receive. Students and faculty members
have a right to know what their representatives said and
how they voted. This is the principal tenet of any system
that is truly open.

voting to evict a News-Letter reporter and
photographer. All the professors present agreed to a
closed meeting while the two undergraduate
representatives voted to allow the News-Letter to stay.

meeting was "routine." During it, the pass-fail proposal
by the Honor Commission was rejected. A matter of
such importance to undergraduates is hardly routine
and needs more amplification than a listing of what the
committee decided.
